name: AGENTS.md
summary: A deceptively simple Markdown file — like README.md but for AI agents — that tells coding agents how to behave in a repo. 60,000+ projects adopted it in months. Its brilliance is its simplicity; its danger is that it's becoming an implicit social expectation. Repos without AGENTS.md may become invisible to agents, creating a soft mandate nobody voted on. The protocol is already transitioning from 'explicit opt-in' to 'social expectation' — Asparouhova's Stage 2.

feedbackLoop.note: Agent behavior changes are immediately observable in code output. Clear cause-and-effect.

edgeCases.note: Simple Markdown format. No edge cases by design — just instructions.

ambiguity.note: Instructions are natural language, interpreted by LLMs. Same AGENTS.md can produce different behavior across models.

redundancy.note: Overlaps with .cursorrules, .claude, CLAUDE.md, and other agent-specific config files.

nesting.note: Flat file. No nesting or recursion possible.

exitCost.note: 60K+ repos. Codex, Cursor, Devin, Gemini CLI, GitHub Copilot all read it. Not having one increasingly means agents work blind in your repo.

identityPenetration.note: Becoming a social norm: 'every serious repo has an AGENTS.md.' Not having one signals you're not AI-ready.

agencyPreservation.note: Developers write the file. Full control over what agents see. But agents choose how to interpret it.

controlInvisibility.note: The standard itself is invisible infrastructure — nobody thinks about whether to adopt it, it just becomes expected. Classic implicit protocol formation.

crisisMindset.note: 'Your repo needs to be agent-ready' — soft urgency driving adoption as table stakes.
